title: Social consequences of COVID-19 on fertility preference consistency and contraceptive use among Nigerian women: insights from population-based data

abstract: Background: Emerging evidence from high income countries showed that the COVID-19 pandemic has had negative effects on population and reproductive health behaviour. This study provides a sub-Saharan Africa perspective by documenting the social consequences of COVID-19 and its relationship to fertility preference stability and modern contraceptive use in Nigeria.
We analysed panel data collected by Performance Monitoring for Action in Nigeria. Baseline and Follow-up surveys were conducted before the COVID-19 outbreak (November 2019-February 2020) and during the lockdown respectively (May-July 2020). Analysis was restricted to married non-pregnant women during follow-up (n = 774). Descriptive statistics and generalized linear models were employed to explore the relationship between selected social consequences of COVID-19 and fertility preferences stability (between baseline and follow-up) as well as modern contraceptives use.
Reported social consequences of the pandemic lockdown include total loss of household income (31.3%), food insecurity (16.5%), and greater economic reliance on partner (43.0%). Sixty-eight women (8.8%) changed their minds about pregnancy and this was associated with age groups, higher wealth quintile (AOR = 0.38, CI: 0.15-0.97) and household food insecurity (AOR = 2.72, CI: 1.23-5.99). Fertility preference was inconsistent among 26.1%. Women aged 30-34 years (AOR = 4.46, CI:1.29-15.39) were more likely of inconsistent fertility preference compared to 15-24 years. The likelihood was also higher among women with three children compared to those with only one child (AOR = 3.88, CI: 1.36-11.08). During follow-up survey, 59.4% reported they would feel unhappy if pregnant. This was more common among women with tertiary education (AOR = 2.99, CI: 1.41-6.33). The odds increased with parity. The prevalence of modern contraceptive use was 32.8%. Women aged 45-49 years (AOR = 0.24, CI: 0.10-0.56) were less likely to use modern contraceptives than those aged 15-24 years. In contrast, the odds of contraceptive use were significantly higher among those with three (AOR = 1.82, CI: 1.03-3.20), four (AOR = 2.45, CI: 1.36-4.39) and at least five

In contrast, the odds of contraceptive use were significantly higher among those with three (AOR = 1.82, CI: 1.03-3.20), four (AOR = 2.45, CI: 1.36-4.39) and at least five'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Abstract'', ''sec_num'': None}], ''body_text'': [{''text'': ''The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic has had diverse consequences on livelihood and health across the globe. Earlier in the outbreak, lockdown, physical distancing, and other public health measures to control the spread caused disruptions to healthcare services and economic activities [1] [2] [3] . The direct and indirect effects of the pandemic and its control measures vary from one context to another. For instance, while the direct effect such as the number of cases and fatalities has been overwhelming in many developed countries but fewer in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), the indirect effects have been sources of concern in most of SSA [4] . The fragile health system and weak economic base in SSA exacerbated the hardship occasioned by lockdown and other containment measures [5] . These multiplier effects have been reported to have negative outlooks for health indices such as sexual and reproductive health (SRH), maternal and child health (MCH), as well as HIV care and treatment services [6] . These are areas where efforts and investment by several stakeholders and development partners have yielded some progress for SSA in the last decade [7] .'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 287, ''end'': 290, ''text'': ''[1]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF0''}, {''start'': 291, ''end'': 294, ''text'': ''[2]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF1''}, {''start'': 295, ''end'': 298, ''text'': ''[3]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF2''}, {''start'': 643, ''end'': 646, ''text'': ''[4]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF3''}, {''start'': 784, ''end'': 787, ''text'': ''[5]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF4''}, {''start'': 1001, ''end'': 1004, ''text'': ''[6]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF5''}, {''start'': 1155, ''end'': 1158, ''text'': ''[7]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF6''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Background'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': "It''s been argued that the fertility trajectories in the post-pandemic era would be driven by effects of the various social measures aimed at its control. And these would vary across developmental context, stage of demographic transition, age structure and availability of modern contraceptives and reproductive technologies [8, 9] . For low-and middle-income countries with poor economic development and limited access to contraceptives, fertility is likely to increase. Emerging evidence on the short-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on sexual and reproductive health (SRH) confirmed some of the projections about service disruptions and its sequalae. For instance, access to family planning services and abortion care were affected in some SSA countries [2, 3, 6] . These could translate into increased unintended pregnancies, unsafe abortions, maternal morbidity, and mortality. Many of the latter issues would require more time for empirical data to accrue.", ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 324, ''end'': 327, ''text'': ''[8,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF7''}, {''start'': 328, ''end'': 330, ''text'': ''9]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF8''}, {''start'': 761, ''end'': 764, ''text'': ''[2,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF1''}, {''start'': 765, ''end'': 767, ''text'': ''3,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF2''}, {''start'': 768, ''end'': 770, ''text'': ''6]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF5''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Background'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''On a positive note, evidence about access to contraceptives and its usage in SSA at the peak of the first COVID-19 lockdown suggests that the problems may not be as grievous as earlier envisaged. For instance, longitudinal data from Kenya and Burkina Faso showed that over a six-month period, there was no change in use of contraceptives among women at risk of unintended pregnancy and the proportion of women who opted for a more effective method was higher [10] . Besides, very few non-contracepting women implicated COVID-19 as reasons for non-use. Furthermore, a similar study that included data from Nigeria and Burkina Faso revealed that the need for and use of contraceptives increased, especially in rural areas of Kenya and Burkina Faso [11] . There were differences across contexts and socio-economic characteristics, which are not unexpected based on past knowledge about the roles of these background variables [10, 11] .'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 459, ''end'': 463, ''text'': ''[10]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF9''}, {''start'': 746, ''end'': 750, ''text'': ''[11]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF10''}, {''start'': 923, ''end'': 927, ''text'': ''[10,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF9''}, {''start'': 928, ''end'': 931, ''text'': ''11]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF10''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Background'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Aside from the foregoing, the fertility or reproductive intentions that drive contraceptive behaviour are also important and deserve empirical assessment in light of COVID-19 lockdown and its aftermaths. Before the pandemic, the literature indicates that women fertility intentions often change over time in response to prevailing economic situations and other considerations such as employment and marital contexts [12] [13] [14] . In the pandemic era, studies conducted in Australia [15] , United Kingdom [16] , the United States [17] , Italy [18] , Poland [19] and Shanghai, China [20] revealed that on the average, about one-third of women or couples who planned pregnancy for Jan-July 2020 postponed their pregnancy intention mostly due to concerns about income loss, access to MCH services and possible effects of COVID-19 on pregnancy. Fertility behaviours in these highincome countries differ from SSA countries, especially those with high fertility.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 416, ''end'': 420, ''text'': ''[12]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF11''}, {''start'': 421, ''end'': 425, ''text'': ''[13]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF12''}, {''start'': 426, ''end'': 430, ''text'': ''[14]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF13''}, {''start'': 485, ''end'': 489, ''text'': ''[15]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF14''}, {''start'': 507, ''end'': 511, ''text'': ''[16]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF15''}, {''start'': 532, ''end'': 536, ''text'': ''[17]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF16''}, {''start'': 545, ''end'': 549, ''text'': ''[18]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF17''}, {''start'': 559, ''end'': 563, ''text'': ''[19]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF18''}, {''start'': 584, ''end'': 588, ''text'': ''[20]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF19''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Background'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''It is widely known that sub-regions of SSA are in different stages of fertility transition [21] . Countries in Southern and Eastern Africa have mostly transited to low fertility regime, while Western and Central Africa have remained persistently high fertility settings with very slow transitions [21, 22] . Therefore, fertility intention and the response to COVID-19 lockdown restrictions may also differ. The pre-pandemic literature on fertility preferences and intentions indicate that there is some level of instability and depend on factors such as household economic status, education, and parity [12, 14, 22] . Assessment of fertility intention and/or preferences provides the necessary benchmark for family planning advocacy and gives insight into future fertility trajectory for a (AOR = 2.89, CI: 1.25-6.74) children. Unhappy disposition towards pregnancy (AOR = 2.48, CI: 1.724-3.58) was also a significant predictor of modern contraceptive use.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 91, ''end'': 95, ''text'': ''[21]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF20''}, {''start'': 297, ''end'': 301, ''text'': ''[21,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF20''}, {''start'': 302, ''end'': 305, ''text'': ''22]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF21''}, {''start'': 603, ''end'': 607, ''text'': ''[12,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF11''}, {''start'': 608, ''end'': 611, ''text'': ''14,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF13''}, {''start'': 612, ''end'': 615, ''text'': ''22]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF21''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Background'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Some social consequences of COVID-19 affected pregnancy intention and stability of fertility preference but showed no independent association with modern contraceptive use.'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Conclusion:'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Keywords: COVID-19 lockdown, Fertility preference, Childbearing intention, Modern contraceptive use, Nigeria population [13] . In addition, fertility intention measures are employed for estimation of family planning needs and demand satisfaction which are important indicators of SDG3 target on family planning uptake.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 120, ''end'': 124, ''text'': ''[13]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF12''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Conclusion:'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''This study aims to provide evidence on childbearing intentions amidst the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria, the most populous country in West Africa. A previous study in the country showed that the proportion of women who wanted more children declined between 2003 and 2013, but this was more likely in the South West region, educated women and urban dwellers. In contrast, the percentage undecided about future childbirth was higher in 2013 compared to 2003 and was associated with parity and discrepancies in desired family sizes among couples [23] . We hypothesise that COVID-19 and its attendant adverse economic effects may heighten the level of uncertainty. Therefore, reproductive-age women may have inconsistent childbearing desires, especially during the lockdown restrictions. To explore these issues, our study aimed to address the following objectives: (i) assess the social consequences of COVID-19 among married women in Nigeria; (ii) investigate short-term changes in childbearing intentions due to COVID-19 concerns; (iii) explore the relationship between social consequences of COVID-19 and stability of fertility preference, and (iv) investigate the implication of social consequences of COVID-19 and stability of fertility preference on modern contraceptive use among married women in Nigeria. Our results provide contextual evidence on the short-term effects of COVID-19 lockdown on fertility intentions among Nigerian women. It can also serve as a benchmark for future studies on the medium and long-term impact of the pandemic on reproductive behaviours.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 542, ''end'': 546, ''text'': ''[23]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF22''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Conclusion:'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''In this study, we analysed data for Lagos and Kano States, the two most populous States in Nigeria, with 2016 projected population of 12.6 million and 13.1 million, respectively [24] . The first case of COVID-19 in Nigeria was detected in late February 2020, with the number of cases rising to 195,890 as of 6th September 2021 and a case fatality of 1.3%. Being the commercial capital, Lagos is the epicentre of the pandemic in Nigeria, with 74,044 cases and 648 deaths as of 6 September 2021. Kano, the commercial hub in the North, has recorded 4102 cases with 111 deaths. Total lockdown and restriction of interstate travels were implemented in the entire country between May and July 2020.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 178, ''end'': 182, ''text'': ''[24]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF23''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Study setting'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''The reproductive health indices in Lagos and Kano States contrast with each other. For instance, while the total fertility rate in Lagos was 3.4, Kano had 6.5.'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Study setting'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Estimates of modern contraceptive prevalence rate in Lagos and Kano was 29.0 and 5.6%, respectively [25] . Underlying these differences are variations in educational attainment and other socio-economic variables.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 100, ''end'': 104, ''text'': ''[25]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF24''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Study setting'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''This study sourced data from Performance Monitoring for Action (PMA) which is a panel survey implemented in nine countries across Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia. PMA collects representative population-based data to monitor trends in selected reproductive health and family planning indicators. Detailed methodology and summary findings from PMA are available online and in previous publications that used the data [10, 11] .'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 421, ''end'': 425, ''text'': ''[10,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF9''}, {''start'': 426, ''end'': 429, ''text'': ''11]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF10''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Data source'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''PMA surveys have been implemented in Nigeria since 2017, with four rounds of data collection successfully conducted. In this study, we analysed data from two rounds. These were the panel baseline survey conducted in December 2019-January 2020 and the follow-up survey which was implemented in May-July 2020 to track reproductive indices in response to the COVID-19 outbreak. Detailed descriptions of the sampling process and data collection for the baseline and COVID-19 followup surveys in Nigeria are available online [26] . In brief, the PMA surveys in Nigeria took place in Lagos and Kano States, where representative data were collected on knowledge and practice of contraceptive use in 52 and 25 enumeration areas (EAs), respectively. The EAs and females aged 15-49 years were selected via a multi-stage stratified cluster design. Data were collected by trained fieldworkers using face-face interviews.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 520, ''end'': 524, ''text'': ''[26]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF25''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Data source'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''The follow-up data collection coincides with the peak of lockdown and other measures introduced to contain further spread of the pandemic in Nigeria. During the follow-up survey, telephone interviews were conducted among baseline respondents who gave consent to be recontacted and had access to a phone. In Lagos and Kano, the follow-up sample was 82.6 and 33.6% of the baseline population, respectively.'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Data source'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Out of the 1603 (Lagos:1174 and Kano:429) respondents eligible for the follow-up survey, 1346 were successfully interviewed. Of this number, we analysed data on a weighted sample of 774 women who were married [married or cohabiting with a man] and not pregnant during the follow-up survey. The follow-up sample was reverse weighted to properly account for phone ownership, consent and completeness of follow-up interview [11, 26] . Pregnant women were excluded from analyses because they did not respond to the questions that constituted our outcome measures in this study.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 421, ''end'': 425, ''text'': ''[11,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF10''}, {''start'': 426, ''end'': 429, ''text'': ''26]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF25''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Analytic sample'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''We analysed four outcome measures described as follows:'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Outcome measures'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''i. Change in pregnancy intention due to COVID-19 concerns. This was analysed as a dichotomous variable coded as Yes (1) "Have a/another child"; "No more/prefer no children"; "Can\''t get pregnant"; "Undecided/ Don\''t know". Any respondent whose response in the follow-up survey differ from their answer at baseline were scategorised as having "inconsistent fertility preference (1)", while those whose responses remained the same between baseline and followup were classified as consistent (0). iii. Disposition to pregnancy: During the follow-up survey, respondents were asked, "If you got pregnant now, how would you feel?". The response categories were: "very happy", "happy", "mixed happy and unhappy", "sort of unhappy", "very unhappy". The first two options were recoded as happy (0), while the other three options were recoded as unhappy (1). iv. Modern contraceptive use: this was a dichotomous variable coded as Yes [1] or no [0] for users and non-users of modern family planning methods respectively.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 116, ''end'': 119, ''text'': ''(1)'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF0''}, {''start'': 922, ''end'': 925, ''text'': ''[1]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF0''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Outcome measures'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''Three categories of explanatory variables were analysed. First are the social consequences of COVID-19 restrictions, which constitute the main independent variables in this study. These were all based on the following data collected in the follow-up survey:'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Explanatory variables'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''(i) Loss of personal income: this was based on the question, "Since Coronavirus restrictions began, how much of a loss of income have you experienced". The options were Large, Moderate, Small, and No income.'', ''cite_spans'': [], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Explanatory variables'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''(ii) Loss of household income: this was based on the question, "Since Coronavirus restrictions began, how much of a loss of income has your household experienced". The response options were None, Complete, Partial. In the data, no respondent selected "none". Therefore, only two categories were reported in the analysis. (iii) Worry about future household finance: this was elicited from response to the question, "Are you worried about the impact of Coronavirus (COVID- 19) on your household\''s finances in the future?" The response was either Yes or No. (iv) Household food insecurity: Participants were rated as having household food insecurity if they answered in the affirmative to the question, "Since Coronavirus restrictions began, did you or any household member go a whole day and night without eating anything because there was not enough food?" (v) Economic reliance on the partner: This was an indicator variable coded as Yes or No. The base question was, "Are you more economically reliant on your husband/partner now than before the Coronavirus restrictions began?" Respondents who answered "Yes" were classified as being economically reliant on the partner.'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 471, ''end'': 474, ''text'': ''19)'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF18''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Explanatory variables'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''The second group of explanatory variables comprises socio-demographic characteristics of participants, and this include age, highest educational attainment, employment, wealth quintile, and type of residence. Age was classified as 15-24, 25-29, 30-34, 35-39, 40-44, 45-49 years. The categories for education include none, primary, secondary, and higher, while employment was a dichotomous variable coded as Yes or No. The type of residence was either rural or urban. Wealth quintile was derived from the application of principal component analysis to various household items possessed by respondents. The first component from PCA was subsequently ranked and divided into 5 categories lowest, lower, middle, higher, and highest. The relationship between these socio-demographic variables and fertility intentions or behaviour is well illustrated in the literature. For instance, there is an inverse relationship between age and fertility desire, such that as age increases, childbearing desire reduces [27] . A similar inverse relationship exists between educational attainment, employment, wealth quintile and fertility [23, 28, 29] .'', ''cite_spans'': [{''start'': 1001, ''end'': 1005, ''text'': ''[27]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF26''}, {''start'': 1120, ''end'': 1124, ''text'': ''[23,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF22''}, {''start'': 1125, ''end'': 1128, ''text'': ''28,'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF27''}, {''start'': 1129, ''end'': 1132, ''text'': ''29]'', ''ref_id'': ''BIBREF28''}], ''ref_spans'': [], ''eq_spans'': [], ''section'': ''Explanatory variables'', ''sec_num'': None}, {''text'': ''The third set of explanatory variables were the marital and reproductive profile of the women. These include the number of times married/cohabited, family type, children-ever-born and history of pregnancy termination in the past 3 years. The number of times married was classified as either one or more than one. Evidence from the literature suggest that women who have been married more than once tend to be pronatal [30, 31] . title: Social consequences of COVID-19 on fertility preference consistency and contraceptive use among Nigerian women: insights from population-based data

{
  "article_classification": "SCIENTIFIC_TEXT",
  "reason": null,
  "summary": {
    "title": "Social consequences of COVID-19 on fertility preference consistency and contraceptive use among Nigerian women: insights from population-based data",
    "authors": "Joshua O. Akinyemi (University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa; joakinyemi@com.ui.edu.ng); Oluwafemi I. Dipeolu (University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria); Ayodeji M. Adebayo (University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria); Babatunde M. Gbadebo (University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria); Grace A. Ajuwon (University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria); Tubosun A. Olowolafe (University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria); Yemi Adewoyin (University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa); Clifford O. Odimegwu (University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa)",
    "publication_year": null,
    "field_subfield": "Public Health â Reproductive Health",
    "type_of_paper": "Empirical observational panel study",
    "executive_summary": "This study examines how the COVID-19 pandemic and associated lockdown measures affected fertility preferences and modern contraceptive use among married, non-pregnant women in Nigeria. Using panel data from Performance Monitoring for Action (PMA) in Lagos and Kano States, the authors analyzed baseline (Dec 2019âFeb 2020) and follow-up (MayâJuly 2020) surveys. The analytic sample comprised 774 married, non-pregnant women (reverse-weighted). Outcomes included: (i) change in pregnancy intention due to COVID-19 concerns (dichotomous), (ii) inconsistent fertility preference between baseline and follow-up, (iii) disposition to pregnancy (happy vs unhappy), and (iv) modern contraceptive use (dichotomous). Exposures captured social consequences of COVID-19 (income loss, food insecurity, worry about future finances, economic reliance on partner), socio-demographics (age, education, employment, wealth quintile, residence), and marital/reproductive factors (marriage history, family type, children ever born [CEB], recent termination).\n\nSocial consequences were substantial: 31.3% reported total loss of household income; 16.5% experienced household food insecurity; 43.0% became more economically reliant on their partner; and 92.4% worried about future household finances. Only 8.8% changed their minds about pregnancy due to COVID-19 concerns. In multivariable models, women in the lower (AOR = 0.32, 95% CI: 0.14â0.76) and higher (AOR = 0.38, 95% CI: 0.15â0.97) wealth quintiles were less likely to change intention than the lowest quintile, while household food insecurity was associated with higher odds (AOR = 2.72, 95% CI: 1.23â5.99). Inconsistent fertility preference was observed in 26.1% of women; ages 30â34 (AOR = 4.46, 95% CI: 1.29â15.39) and women with three CEB (AOR = 3.88, 95% CI: 1.36â11.08) relative to one CEB had higher odds. During follow-up, 59.4% reported they would feel unhappy if pregnant; tertiary education (AOR = 2.99, 95% CI: 1.41â6.33) and higher parity increased odds of being unhappy. Modern contraceptive use prevalence was 32.8% at follow-up; women aged 45â49 had lower odds than ages 15â24 (AOR = 0.24, 95% CI: 0.10â0.56), while higher parity (3 CEB: AOR = 1.82, 95% CI: 1.03â3.20; 4 CEB: AOR = 2.45, 95% CI: 1.36â4.39; â¥5 CEB: AOR = 2.89, 95% CI: 1.25â6.74) and an unhappy disposition (AOR = 2.48, 95% CI: 1.72â3.58) were associated with higher odds of use. Notably, none of the social consequences of COVID-19 were independently associated with modern contraceptive use.\n\nFindings suggest that economic shocks and food insecurity were linked to unstable fertility intentions, whereas contraceptive use patterns were more strongly associated with background characteristics and emotional disposition to pregnancy. The study provides early evidence from Nigeria that, despite pandemic-related disruptions, contraceptive use did not decline and that unhappiness about pregnancy may be a promising lever for family planning promotion. Limitations include short-term follow-up during peak lockdown, telephone-based follow-up, potential selection bias, and lack of sexual behavior data. The results are context-specific to Lagos and Kano and should not be generalized to Nigeria as a whole.",
    "research_context": "Early in the pandemic, lockdowns and service disruptions raised concerns about adverse impacts on sexual and reproductive health in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), including potential increases in unintended pregnancies and maternal morbidity/mortality. Prior high-income country studies reported substantial postponement of pregnancy intentions due to economic and service disruptions. In contrast, emerging SSA evidence suggested contraceptive use remained stable or increased in some settings, with context and socio-economic differences. Nigeria, a high-fertility SSA country, had not yet experienced the same magnitude of mortality as high-income countries. The study addresses a gap by providing population-based evidence from Nigeria on how COVID-19-related social consequences relate to fertility preference stability and modern contraceptive use, complementing longitudinal findings from Kenya and Burkina Faso and informing SDG3 family planning targets. It also explores whether pandemic-era emotional disposition to pregnancy correlates with contraceptive uptake, offering a potential behavioral lever for family planning communication.",
    "research_question_and_hypothesis": "Research questions: (i) What were the social consequences of COVID-19 among married women in Nigeria? (ii) Did COVID-19 concerns lead to short-term changes in childbearing intentions? (iii) How were social consequences of COVID-19 associated with stability of fertility preferences? (iv) What were the implications of social consequences and fertility preference stability for modern contraceptive use?\n\nHypotheses: The authors hypothesized that adverse economic effects of COVID-19 would heighten uncertainty and lead to inconsistent childbearing desires, particularly during lockdown. They further anticipated that background characteristics (age, education, employment, wealth, parity) would continue to shape fertility preferences and contraceptive use, and that emotional disposition to pregnancy might be associated with contraceptive uptake. Outcomes supporting the hypotheses would include higher odds of changing pregnancy intention and inconsistent preferences among those experiencing economic hardship (e.g., food insecurity), and associations between parity and education with contraceptive use. Null findings for social consequences predicting contraceptive use would suggest resilience of contraceptive behavior to pandemic-related shocks.",
    "methodological_details": "Design and setting: Population-based panel survey using PMA data in Lagos and Kano States, Nigeria, two of the most populous states. The first COVID-19 case in Nigeria was detected in late February 2020; by 6 September 2021, Nigeria had 195,890 cases and a 1.3% case fatality rate. Lagos (epicenter) recorded 74,044 cases and 648 deaths; Kano had 4,102 cases and 111 deaths. Total lockdown and interstate travel restrictions were implemented nationwide between May and July 2020.\n\nData sources and sampling: PMA conducts representative surveys across SSA and Southeast Asia. In Nigeria, four rounds have been conducted since 2017. This study used baseline (Dec 2019âJan 2020) and follow-up (MayâJuly 2020) rounds. Sampling employed a multi-stage stratified cluster design in 52 enumeration areas (EAs) in Lagos and 25 EAs in Kano, with females aged 15â49 selected. Baseline data collection was face-to-face; follow-up used telephone interviews among baseline respondents who consented to recontact and had a phone. Follow-up samples were 82.6% (Lagos) and 33.6% (Kano) of baseline populations.\n\nAnalytic sample: Of 1,603 eligible for follow-up (Lagos: 1,174; Kano: 429), 1,346 were successfully interviewed. The analytic sample included a reverse-weighted subset of 774 married (married or cohabiting with a man) and non-pregnant women during follow-up. Pregnant women were excluded because they did not respond to intention/outcome measures.\n\nOutcomes: (i) Change in pregnancy intention due to COVID-19 concerns: dichotomous (1 = changed; 0 = consistent), defined by discordance between baseline and follow-up responses to pregnancy intention categories. (ii) Inconsistent fertility preference: dichotomous (1 = inconsistent; 0 = consistent) between baseline and follow-up. (iii) Disposition to pregnancy: dichotomous (happy vs unhappy) based on follow-up response to feeling if pregnant now. (iv) Modern contraceptive use: dichotomous (1 = user; 0 = non-user) of modern methods.\n\nExposures: Social consequences of COVID-19 (follow-up): loss of personal income (small, moderate, large, none), loss of household income (partial, total; none not selected), worry about future household finance (yes/no), household food insecurity (yes/no), economic reliance on partner (yes/no). Socio-demographics: age (15â24, 25â29, 30â34, 35â39, 40â44, 45â49), highest education (none, primary, secondary, tertiary), employment (yes/no), residence (urban/rural), wealth quintile (lowest, lower, middle, higher, highest; derived via PCA of household assets). Marital/reproductive: number of times married/cohabited (once vs more than once), family type (monogamy vs polygyny), children ever born (CEB: â¤1, 2, 3, 4, â¥5), history of pregnancy termination in past 3 years (yes/no).\n\nStatistical analysis: Descriptive statistics summarized characteristics and outcomes. For change in pregnancy intention (rare outcome), a complementary log-log model was used; for other outcomes, binomial logit models were applied. Model building proceeded in stages: (1) univariate models (one variable at a time) to estimate unadjusted ORs; (2) multivariable models including all social consequences; (3) final models including variables with p<0.1 from univariate and stage two. Robust standard errors, sampling weights, and clustering by EA were used. Ethics: Protocol approved by Lagos State University Teaching Hospital Health Research Ethics Committee; written informed consent obtained; PMA approved data retrieval; final data were de-identified.",
    "procedures_and_architectures": "The study employed a structured observational analytic pipeline on panel survey data. Procedures included: (1) Data harmonization and restriction to married, non-pregnant women at follow-up; (2) Construction of outcome variables from baseline and follow-up responses, including dichotomization of pregnancy intention change and disposition to pregnancy; (3) Derivation of wealth quintiles via PCA of household assets; (4) Specification of generalized linear models tailored to outcome distributions: complementary log-log for the rare event (change in intention) and binomial logit for other outcomes; (5) Multivariable model building in stages to isolate independent associations of social consequences while controlling for socio-demographics and reproductive factors; (6) Inclusion of robust standard errors and sampling weights to account for complex survey design and clustering by enumeration area; (7) Interpretation of adjusted odds ratios (AORs) with 95% confidence intervals.\n\nNo computational architectures, machine learning, or experimental interventions were used. The core analytic apparatus comprised standard generalized linear modeling with careful handling of survey design features. The authors report model forms (complementary log-log and logit) and the inclusion of covariates, but do not provide software specifications, random seeds, or additional sensitivity analyses beyond the staged modeling approach.",
    "key_results": "Sample characteristics: Mean age 35.2 years (SD = 7.5). Age groups 30â34 (23.4%) and 35â39 (23.3%) were most represented. Education: none 13.4%, secondary 39.2%, tertiary 30.5%. Employment: 82.8% employed; residence: 81.8% urban. Marital profile: 90.3% married/cohabited once; 21.1% polygynous. CEB distribution was even across â¤1, 2, 3, 4, â¥5; 9.0% reported a pregnancy termination in the past 3 years.\n\nSocial consequences: Moderate to large loss of personal income was reported by about half; total loss of household income by 31.3%; household food insecurity by 16.5%; 92.4% worried about future household finance; 43.0% became more economically reliant on their partner.\n\nChange in pregnancy intention: 68/774 (8.8%) changed their minds. Univariate associations included lower odds with higher age and wealth quintiles, and higher odds with food insecurity and partner reliance. In multivariable models, lower (AOR = 0.32, 95% CI: 0.14â0.76) and higher (AOR = 0.38, 95% CI: 0.15â0.97) wealth quintiles were less likely to change intention than the lowest quintile; household food insecurity increased odds (AOR = 2.72, 95% CI: 1.23â5.99). Economic reliance on partner was not significant in the final model (AOR = 1.80, 95% CI: 0.82â3.96).\n\nInconsistent fertility preference: 202/774 (26.1%) were inconsistent. Ages 30â34 (AOR = 4.46, 95% CI: 1.29â15.39) and women with three CEB (AOR = 3.88, 95% CI: 1.36â11.08) had higher odds than ages 15â24 and one CEB, respectively. Household food insecurity was associated with higher odds in intermediate models (AOR = 1.64, 95% CI: 1.01â2.68) but not in the final model.\n\nDisposition to pregnancy: 59.4% reported they would feel unhappy if pregnant. Tertiary education (AOR = 2.99, 95% CI: 1.41â6.33) and higher parity increased odds of being unhappy; urban residence was associated with higher odds (AOR = 2.99 in unadjusted; adjusted AOR = 0.57, 95% CI: 0.25â1.30). Loss of personal income categories were associated with lower odds of being unhappy in adjusted models (e.g., moderate AOR = 0.45, 95% CI: 0.22â0.89; large AOR = 0.47, 95% CI: 0.23â0.93).\n\nModern contraceptive use (MCP): Prevalence was 32.8% at follow-up (30.1% baseline; +2.7 percentage points). MCP peaked at ages 35â39 (41.0%) and was lowest at 45â49 (23.2%). Education increased MCP (none 15.5% vs tertiary 41.3%). Urban residence was associated with higher odds (unadjusted OR = 2.63; adjusted OR = 0.56, 95% CI: 0.17â1.79). In adjusted models, women aged 45â49 had lower odds than ages 15â24 (AOR = 0.24, 95% CI: 0.09â0.69). Higher parity increased odds (3 CEB: AOR = 1.82, 95% CI: 1.03â3.20; 4 CEB: AOR = 2.45, 95% CI: 1.36â4.39; â¥5 CEB: AOR = 2.89, 95% CI: 1.25â6.74). Unhappy disposition to pregnancy was strongly associated with higher odds of MCP (AOR = 2.48, 95% CI: 1.72â3.58). None of the social consequences of COVID-19 were independently associated with MCP.\n\nComparative patterns: Baseline vs follow-up intention stability showed that 81.6% of women who wanted another child at baseline remained so; 47.2% of undecided at baseline wanted a child at follow-up, while 26.7% remained undecided. MCP was higher among women with an unhappy disposition (41.5%) than those happy (19.3%).",
    "interpretation_and_theoretical_implications": "Economic shocks and food insecurity during COVID-19 were linked to unstable fertility intentions among Nigerian women, consistent with theories that fertility preferences are sensitive to household economic conditions. The lack of association between social consequences and modern contraceptive use suggests resilience of contraceptive behavior to pandemic-related disruptions, aligning with SSA evidence that contraceptive uptake did not decline. The strong association between unhappy disposition to pregnancy and higher odds of contraceptive use indicates that emotional readiness and ideational profiles are actionable levers for family planning promotion. Background factors (age, education, parity) maintained expected relationships with fertility preferences and contraceptive use, reinforcing established demographic patterns. The findings imply that communication strategies emphasizing emotional preparedness for pregnancy could enhance contraceptive uptake, while targeted support for food-insecure households may stabilize fertility intentions. The scope is limited to Lagos and Kano and short-term lockdown conditions; generalization to Nigeriaâs national context requires caution.",
    "contradictions_and_limitations": "Key limitations include: (1) Short-term follow-up during peak lockdown; medium- and long-term fertility and contraceptive trajectories remain unknown. (2) Telephone-based follow-up may differ from face-to-face interviews, though the authors argue patterns are unlikely to change. (3) Selection bias: not all baseline respondents were recontacted; Kano had substantial dropout (33.6% follow-up), potentially biasing estimates upward if those consenting were more educated/wealthy. (4) Lack of sexual behavior data precludes assessing whether changes in sexual activity mediated effects on intentions or contraceptive use. (5) External validity: Lagos and Kano represent extremes of modern contraceptive prevalence in Nigeria; results should not be generalized nationally. (6) Some model coefficients differ slightly across tables (e.g., MCP age 45â49 AOR 0.24 vs 0.24 in text), indicating minor inconsistencies in reporting. (7) The study cannot establish causality; associations may be confounded by unmeasured factors. (8) No details on random seeds, software, or additional sensitivity analyses are provided, limiting reproducibility beyond the reported models.",

    "three_takeaways": "First, the study provides population-based evidence from Nigeria that COVID-19-related economic shocks and food insecurity were associated with unstable fertility intentions, while contraceptive use remained resilient and was strongly linked to parity, age, and emotional disposition to pregnancy. This underscores the importance of social protection and ideation-focused family planning strategies during crises.\n\nSecond, the strongest quantitative signals include: 8.8% changed pregnancy intention (AORs for lower/higher wealth 0.32/0.38; food insecurity 2.72), 26.1% inconsistent fertility preference (age 30â34 AOR 4.46; parity 3 AOR 3.88), 59.4% unhappy disposition (tertiary education AOR 2.99), and 32.8% modern contraceptive use (age 45â49 AOR 0.24; parity 3/4/â¥5 AORs 1.82/2.45/2.89; unhappy disposition AOR 2.48). These effect sizes quantify the relative risks and opportunities for intervention.\n\nThird, limitationsâshort-term lockdown context, telephone follow-up, potential selection bias, and lack of sexual behavior dataâconstrain causal inference and generalizability. The results are specific to Lagos and Kano and should not be extrapolated nationally without caution. Nonetheless, the findings suggest that unhappiness about pregnancy is a practical lever for increasing contraceptive uptake and that food insecurity is a key determinant of unstable fertility intentions."
